proverb: I can't talk now, I'm having dinner. Can you call back later?
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal.Also, the verb 'have' is used in the continuous form here and means 'experiencing' or 'taking', although it is mostly used as a stative verb.

proverb: We organized a dinner for Dad's birthday.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal

proverb: We didn't like the dinner.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal

proverb: I am not hungry right now. I had a big breakfast.
description: This sentence demonstrates the use of articles with meals (breakfast/lunch/dinner). We do not usually use articles with meals (uncount nouns), unless it is a specific meal

proverb: I've never tried Korean food.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use 'the' with nationl cuisines

proverb: The train to Paris leaves from platform 2.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: Excuse me sir, can you tell me where I might find platform 9 3/4?
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: My English class is in room 6 on the first floor.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: See figures 1 and 2 on pages 3 and 4 for details.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use the definite article with following constructs: noun + number (page 6, platform 9, room 5)

proverb: Man is mortal.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense

proverb: What kind of bird is it?
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense

proverb: Man is the only animal that cooks food.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we do not use articles (definite or indefinite) when a common noun is used in its widest sense

proverb: There aren't many people who have read this novel to the end.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns

proverb: Fewer people smoke these days than used to.
description: This sentence demonstrates what determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. Also we use the following expression 'used to + infinitive' when we talk about habits or repeated actions in the past which we don't do anymore in the present. In this example it is not followed directly by an infinitive but the effect is the same

proverb: There were few people on the beach because it was raining.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns, and also when to use 'few' and 'a few'

proverb: I have a number of things I want to talk to you about. He has a good job and makes a large amount of money.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'number of' and when to use 'amount of' with count/uncount nouns

proverb: We need to go to the greengrocer's. There are few potatoes left.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns, and also when to use 'few' and 'a few'

proverb: No need to hurry! We still have a few hours left.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns, and also when to use 'few' and 'a few'

proverb: Our teacher gives us too much homework.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'too much' and 'too many'. We use 'too much' with uncout and 'too many' with count nouns in negative sentences, when we want to express that we don't like something

proverb: I've got a little money saved, I think I'll buy a new bike.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: There's very little snow in the street. We don't need the snow boots.
description: These sentences demonstrate which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And we typically use 'on' with streets, roads, avenues when we mean somewhere on a street, but here we say 'in the street' because we mean the carriageway (проезжая часть) and it is an enclosed space (we use the preposition 'in' with enclosed spaces).

proverb: Hurry up! We have very little time left. Don't worry! We still have a little time left.
description: These sentences demonstrate which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: I have a number of things I want to talk to you about. The amount of time it took to finish the job was very frustrating.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'number of' and when to use 'amount of' with count/uncount nouns

proverb: I speak a little English, so when I'm in England I don't have problems.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: The woman we met yesterday spoke little English and we couldn't really understand her.
description: This sentence demonstrates which determiners and quantifiers must be used with countable and uncountable nouns. And also it demonstrates the difference between 'a little' and 'little'

proverb: I went to the market and bought a lot of fruit.
description: This sentence demonstrates that we can use 'a lot of' with both count and uncount nouns. 'fruit' is usually uncountable.

proverb: Oh God, there's too many people!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'too much' and 'too many'. We use 'too much' with uncout and 'too many' with count nouns in negative sentences, when we want to express that we don't like something

proverb: I drank too much coffee, and now I feel sick. I drank a lot of beer, and now I feel good.
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'much', 'many' and 'a lot of'. We tend to use 'many' and 'much' in questions and negatives, and use 'lots of' or 'a lot of' in affirmative statements

proverb: Time passes quickly. I had a nice time at the cinema.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the noun 'time' can be both count and non-count

proverb: There are times in life when people must know when not to let go.
description: This sentence demonstrates that the noun 'time' can be both count and non-count

proverb: How many times did I tell you?
description: This sentence demonstrates that the noun 'time' can be both count and non-count

proverb: My country does a lot of business with Argentina. My brother's self-employed, he owns a small business.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the noun 'business' can be both count and non-count

proverb: After dinner, I usually go for a walk in the wood near our house. I can't tell if this table is made of wood or plastic.
description: These two sentences demonstrate that the noun 'wood' can be both count and non-count. 'Dinner' is also a non-count noun.

proverb: All Sam's children have long, fair hair. Excuse me, waiter, but there's a hair in my soup.
description: These sentences demonstrate that the noun 'hair' can be both count and non-count

proverb: The train was scheduled to arrive on time at 13:36. Luckily we made it just in time!
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'on time' and when to use 'in time'

proverb: I didn't arrive at the cinema on time, but I still arrived in time to see the whole film.
description: These sentences demonstrate when to use 'on time' and when to use 'in time'. It also demonstrates that the verb 'arrive' indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it. We alwas say 'arrived at the cinema', not 'arrived to the cinema'

proverb: You mean to tell me you have never ridden a horse before?
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'ride'. We ride something if we are on top of it (верхом): ride a bicycle, horse, bike, tiger, etc

proverb: The West End is easy to reach by Tube.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions

proverb: The quickest way to get there is by air.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use transportation prepositions

proverb: Today is a brand new day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions before Today, Tomorrow or Yesterday because these are uncountable nouns

proverb: The air is so clean at sunrise.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: I'll be asleep at midnight!
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dinner, etc). 'at night' is an exception and needs to be memorized.

proverb: I'll be there at dawn.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: I'll go shopping at lunchtime.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'at lunchtime', 'at dinnertime', at 'suppertime', 'at dinner', 'at breakfast', etc when we mean the time, not the meal - за обедом, за ужином)

proverb: I ate too much at dinner.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'at lunchtime', 'at dinnertime', at 'suppertime', 'at dinner', 'at breakfast', etc when we mean the time, not the meal - за обедом, за ужином)

proverb: At breakfast, he didn't say a word, just read his newspaper.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'at lunchtime', 'at dinnertime', at 'suppertime', 'at dinner', 'at breakfast', etc when we mean the time, not the meal - за обедом, за ужином)

proverb: I read my daughter a story at bedtime.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: He wrote this book at the age of twenty.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times within one day (twenty-four hours to be precise): at 3pm, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime, etc. But 'at' is also often used when talking about someone's age. It is most often used when talking about the past, and sometimes the future: I started driving at 16(I started driving when I was 16), I will be a millionaire at 40

proverb: He doesn't like driving at night.
description: The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dinner, etc). 'at night' is an exception and needs to be memorized.

proverb: We went for a walk along the beach at twilight.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at 3pm, at noon, at midnight, at dawn, at dinner, at lunchtime, at bedtime).

proverb: We are visiting friends and relatives at Christmas. We'll be opening our gifts on Christmas Day.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean the whole holiday period. In the second - only one day

proverb: Did you have a good time at Easter? What will you be doing on Easter Sunday?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean the whole holiday period. In the second - only one day

proverb: What are you doing on New Year's Day? What are you doing at New Year's?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In the first sentece we mean only one day, January 1. In the second - the whole holiday period (few days around that time in general). We can also say on New Year's Eve and it also means one day - December 31

proverb: Let's have a coffee on Friday morning. Where did you go on Thursday night? I'm usually available on Monday and Friday afternoons.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. We use the preposition 'on' with parts of the day

proverb: I'm going to go shopping on the weekend. What are you doing on the weekend? What did you do on the weekend?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend.  It can also be used in its plural form (on weekends / on the weekends) when we're talking about someting habitual

proverb: We go out once in a while on the weekends. We go out once in a while on weekends.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend.  It can also be used in its plural form (on weekends / on the weekends) when we're talking about someting habitual

proverb: They usually go windsurfing on the weekends. They usually go windsurfing on weekends.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend.  It can also be used in its plural form (on weekends / on the weekends) when we're talking about someting habitual

proverb: On the weekends, I like to watch football. On weekends, I like to watch football.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. In American English we use 'on' with weekends, in British English we use 'at'. Weekend is mostly used in singular form (always preceded with 'the') and can mean either a specific weekend (previous or upcoming) or any weekend.  It can also be used in its plural form (on weekends / on the weekends) when we're talking about someting habitual

proverb: The kids have been on vacation two weeks.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'on vacation' and 'on holiday'

proverb: When I was on holiday in Cancun I caught swine fever.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We say 'on vacation' and 'on holiday'

proverb: The printing press was invented in the Middle Ages.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the preposition 'in' with months, seasons, years, centuries and other long periods. We also need to use the definite article when talking about centuries, decades and historic periods

proverb: It's too hot to go out in the middle of the day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We always say 'in the middle of something'

proverb: You can drive around the island in a day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to specify a certain amount of time required to do something: in an hour, in a day, in two weeks, etc

proverb: I haven't seen her in years.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to emphasize the length of time that has passed since a past event: in hours, in days, in two weeks, in years, etc

proverb: I'll meet you in an hour.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc

proverb: I'll be ready in 5 minutes.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <a period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc

proverb: He's gone away but he'll be back in a couple of days.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc

proverb: We have class in two hours.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use the following construct 'in + <period of time>' when we need to explain when something will happen in the future: in a day, in two weeks, in a month, etc. It also demonstrates that the noun 'class' has two meanings: a period of time in which students are taught something, or a group of students who are taught together. In this example class means a period of time.

proverb: I woke up early in the morning. I'm going to the library in the evening. Does she sleep in the afternoon?
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. We always say 'in the morning' or 'in the evening'

proverb: Luckily we arrived just in time, we still have 5 minutes!
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use 'on time' and when to use 'in time'

proverb: The show should be finished by 9 p.m. Please return these books by Friday.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than'

proverb: We need to be there by noon. I will be at the restaurant by 8 p.m.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than'

proverb: This animal always hunts by night.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. The preposition 'by' is used to indicate the end time of an activity, meaning 'no later than'. For example: 'We need to be there by noon'. But this is an exception to the rule. 'By night' means по ночам

proverb: I will be at the restaurant by 8 p.m. I will be at the restaurant until 8 p.m.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. These two sentences have two different meanings depending on which preposition is used

proverb: Are you nervous about singing in front of your parents tonight?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words such as 'tonight/next/this/last/every/recently/etc'

proverb: I was waiting for you all day.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words such as 'all day/tonight/next/this/last/every/recently/etc'

proverb: The train leaves tomorrow morning. I have a test tomorrow morning.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words, specifically when we say 'tomorrow + part of day' or 'yesterday + part of day'

proverb: She was in the hospital the day before yesterday. We're flying to Mexico the day after tomorrow.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. 'The day before yesterday' and 'the day after tomorrow' are set expressions that don't require any additional prepositions. Also notice that 'she was in the hospital' means she was a patient receiving care or treatment, not just visiting the hospital.

proverb: I took him to the bus station yesterday evening.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words, specifically with 'tomorrow' and 'yesterday' and also when we say 'tomorrow + part of day' or 'yesterday + part of day'

proverb: Recently, my eyes have been bothering me.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of time. We use no prepositions with certain words such as 'all day/tonight/next/this/last/every/recently/etc'

proverb: We signed the deal a week ago. I'm not sure where I'll be a year from now.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of time. 'a week ago', 'a month ago', 'a year from now' are set expressions that don't require any additional prepositions

proverb: We told him about it the following day. The weeks following the riots were extremely tense.
description: These two sentences demonstate the difference between 'the following' and 'following'. When we say 'the following + (day, month, year, etc)' we mean 'next' (на следующий). In the second sentence 'following' means 'after'

proverb: They arranged to have dinner the following month. Following the dinner, there will be a dance.
description: These two sentences demonstate the difference between 'the following' and 'following'. When we say 'the following + (day, month, year, etc)' we mean 'next' (на следующий). In the second sentence 'following' means 'after'

proverb: Wear a sweater but carry a gun
description: This sentence demonstrates when we use the verb 'wear' and when we use the verb 'carry'

proverb: She is wearing a ring on her finger.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'wear' (wear is used with clothes, jewelry, makeup and perfume), and we use it in the continuous form when we want to describe the action of wearing something, because it is something that is taking place over time or was taking place over time: 'She was wearing...'. The simple form is usually used to express a habitual action. Compare: 'The girl is wearing a black dress' means she is wearing it at the moment, 'The girl wears a black dress every time she goes to church' means on a regular basis but not necessarily at the moment. It also demonstrates when to use the preposition 'on' (when something is attached to something else)

proverb: I used to wear too much makeup, but not anymore.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'wear' (wear is used with clothes, jewelry, makeup and perfume)

proverb: She helped me to carry my suitcases.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'carry' (когда что-то несется в руке или в руках, в кармане). It is also very common to hear the phrase 'to carry a child' which means to be pregnant (to be with child): 'She is carrying my child - она вынашивает моего ребенка, она беременна моим ребенком'

proverb: Your body is not ready to carry a baby. She is carrying my child.
description: The most common use of the verb 'carry' is to hold something or someone with your hands, arms, or on your back and transport it. It is also very common to hear the phrase 'to carry a child' which means to be pregnant/to be with child: 'She is carrying my child - она вынашивает моего ребенка, она беременна моим ребенком'. It is used in the continuous form because it is something that is taking place over time (very similar to 'wear'). It can also be interpreted literally, for example: 'The dad was carrying the child, and his wife was next to him when they were crossing the street.'

proverb: The police in Britain, the Irish Republic and New Zealand don't usually carry guns.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'carry' (когда что-то несется в руке или в руках, в кармане). It also demonstrates that 'police' is normally a plural, collective noun, so we always say 'The police are', but it can be followed by singular verbs when it is thought of as a single unit (The police force, the Police Department)

proverb: I always carry it in my pocket.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'carry' (когда что-то несется в руке или в руках, в кармане). It is also very common to hear the phrase 'to carry a child' which means to be pregnant (to be with child): 'She is carrying my child - она вынашивает моего ребенка, она беременна моим ребенком'

proverb: How much money did you make last year? How much money have you made this year?
description: This sentence demonstrates the difference between the past simple and the present perfect. And also when to use 'last' or 'the last'

proverb: We all have our cross to bear.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the verb 'bear' (нести груз, нести тяжесть, нести на себе, вынести, вынашивать, терпеть)

proverb: I'm at John's house. I had a coffee at Helen's house. He is at his aunt's.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific places, public places, shops, hotels, homes etc. We often say: I am at John's or she is at her aunt's (the implication is John's house or aunt's house)

proverb: My friend works at the hospital downtown.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: He was so sick he spent a week in the hospital.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: Jack had an accident last week. He was taken to the hospital. He is still in the hospital now. Jill has gone to the hospital to visit Jack. She is at the hospital now.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: I am at the movie theater.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific places, public places, shops, hotels, homes, theaters, etc

proverb: He works at Burger King on Bay Street.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific places, public places, shops, hotels, homes, theaters, etc

proverb: They are sitting at the table. They are sitting on the table.
description: These sentences explain how to use prepositions of place.

proverb: We arrived at the airport. I'm arriving in London tomorrow. The movie will be over by the time we arrive at the theater.
description: These sentences demonstrate what prepositions to use with the verb 'arrive'. 'arrive' is a verb that indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it (or no prepositions, for example: arrive home, arrive yesterday, arrive next week).

proverb: We arrived home yesterday.
description: This sentence demonstrates what prepositions to use with the verb 'arrive'. 'arrive' is a verb that indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it (or no prepositions, for example: arrive home, arrive yesterday, arrive next week).

proverb: I'll be arriving on Friday and leaving the following Thursday.
description: This sentence demonstrates what prepositions to use with the verb 'arrive'. 'arrive' is a verb that indicates location or time, but not movement, so we use the usual prepositions of place or time after it (or no prepositions, for example: arrive home, arrive yesterday, arrive next week).

proverb: He was sitting at the top of the stairs.
description: This sentence explains how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'at the top of', or 'at the bottom of'

proverb: The museum is at the end of the street.
description: This sentence explains how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'at the end of', 'at the center of', 'at the beginning of', 'at the back of', etc

proverb: He was crying at the back of the classroom.
description: This sentence explains how to use prepositions of place. We always say 'at the end of', 'at the center of', 'at the back of', 'at the beginning of'

proverb: I'll meet you at the corner of Beach Street and Park Road. The supermarket is on the corner of Martin Street. I saw it in the corner of the room.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, 'at the corner' means near or adjacent to a corner, can also be used to refer to the corner when two streets intersect each other. We use 'on the corner' when the corner is outside, usually when something is located on the corner, for example a building or shop. And we use 'in the corner' when the corner is inside

proverb: He will meet us at the corner of the street. This shop is on the corner of High Street. I saw it in the corner of the room.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, 'at the corner' means near or adjacent to a corner, can also be used to refer to the corner when two streets intersect each other. We use 'on the corner' when the corner is outside, usually when something is located on the corner, for example a building or shop. And we use 'in the corner' when the corner is inside

proverb: We met at a party. We met at a wedding.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with events

proverb: He's speaking at the conference later this week. I don't want to see her at the party tonight.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with events

proverb: I live on Hill Road. Don't walk in the street, it's dangerous! Walk here on the sidewalk. I am at Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Typically, we use the preposition 'on' with streets, roads, avenues when we mean somewhere on a street, but not specific address. 'in the street' literally means the carriageway (проезжая часть). The last sentence means specific address where two streets intersect.

proverb: You have something on your face.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'on' with flat or spherical surfaces (floor, shelf, table, wall, map, page, Earth, moon, etc)

proverb: The poem is on page 44.

When we talk about information represented on paper, we say 'in a book, newspaper, magazine, letter', but 'on a page'

'on the left' means 'слева', it means location that's why it is used with the preposition of place 'on'. 'to the left' means 'налево', it means direction, that's why it is used with the preposition of movement/direction 'to'

proverb: What's that on the water?

proverb: The teacher wrote her name up on the board. She started in the firm by making the tea and now she's on the board. Welcome on board!

In the second sentence 'board' means a high-level group of people where members are elected or hired (and can be thought of as some kind of platform). The last sentence is used literally when welcoming someone to board a public vehicle, which is also considered a platform: plane, train, ship, or bus, etc, or figuratively when welcoming a new member of a team

proverb: She has served on the committee for the last fifteen years.

proverb: He has never been the same since.
description: This sentence demonstrates when to use the Present Perfect Tense. We usually use the Present Perfect Continuous for something that started in the past and still continues in the present, but the verb 'be' is a stative verb in this context and can't be used with continuous tenses, that's why the PP is used. Similar examples: I've known him for years (and I still know him). Sam has had this car since 2012 (Sam still has his car).

'in school' means the person is studying in general but not necessarily inside the school building at that moment. 'school' can also mean a building where children/adults receive education

proverb: My friend works at the hospital downtown. Unfortunately, Mr Brown is in the hospital. He broke his leg.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. Specifically, we say 'at the hospital' when we mean somebody just visiting the hospital or working there (being on the premises of the hospital), but not as a patient. We say 'in the hospital' when we mean somebody being an in-patient at the hospital. However, in certain circumstances 'in the hospital' could mean literally inside the hospital building: 'Sam was in the hospital when it caught fire.'

proverb: I've got the key in my pocket. There's nothing left in my cup. There's some milk in the fridge.

proverb: Standing between the two adults was a small child.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди)

proverb: On the train I was sitting between two very large men.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). It also demonstrates when to use the preposition 'on' when talking about transport

proverb: There are many differences between English and Arabic.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди)

proverb: There is a trade agreement between Mexico, Canada and the US. Trade agreements exist among countries.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The first sentence also demonstrates when to use the definite article with country names

proverb: Among the books, I saw an old photo. I walked among the trees. There is a traitor among us.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между).

proverb: The donations were distributed among the charities.
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между).

proverb: If you walk between those two trees at exactly midnight, a secret gate to another world will open. When you walk among the trees at night, the moonlight looks lovely in your hair.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of place and time. The preposition 'between' is used when talking about two items, or sometimes 3+ items when the quantity is specified (между). The preposition 'among' is used when talking about 3+ items and the quantity is not specified or distinct (среди). The preposition of time 'at' is generally used in reference to specific times on the clock or points of time in the day (at noon, at midnight, at dinner, etc). 'at night' is an exception that needs to be memorized.

proverb:
- May I be excused?
- No, you may not.
description: This sentence demonstrates when and how to use the modal verb 'may'. In this example it is used to ask for permission and grant permission. (we can also use 'can' and 'could' to ask for permission, but 'may' is the most polite modal verb to use with permissions)

proverb: We drove to the airport. We arrived at the airport.
description: These sentences demonstrate the difference between 'to' and 'at'. The preposition 'to' suggests movement, it is a preposition of movement or direction, 'at' suggests a location in place or time. We always say 'arrive at/arrive in' because this verb indicates location, not movement

proverb: The boy on the left is the shortest. The beers to the right of the door, soft drinks to the left.
description: These sentences demonstrate the difference between 'on the left' and 'to the left'. 'on the left' means 'слева', it means location that's why it is used with the preposition of place 'on'. 'to the left' means 'налево', it means direction, that's why it is used with the preposition of movement/direction 'to'

proverb: She smiled at me. They waved at us as we drove by. She aimed at the target. Don't yell at me!
description: In these sentences 'at' is used as a preposition of direction. The preposition 'at' is usually used as a preposition of location in space or time. But certain verbs are used in combination with this preposition to show direction.

proverb: She threw a stone to me. She threw a stone at me.
description: In these two sentences the prepositions 'to' and 'at' mean the same - direction. But the first sentence means 'бросила камень мне', while the second sentence means 'бросила камень в меня'

proverb: It took us three days to drive across the desert. David walked slowly through the woods.
description: These two sentences demonstrate the difference between two prepositions of movement: across and through. 'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something. It is also used when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it.

'across' expresses movement from one side to the other side of something with clear limits such as a city, road or river. The movement is on the surface of something. It is also used when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. The movement is inside something, we are surrounded by it.

It is also used when something touches or stretches from one side to another. 'through' expresses movement into one side and out of the other side of something. proverb: We went for a walk along the beach at twilight.
description: 'along' is a preposition used to show movement of something in a line that follows the direction of something long.

proverb: They rode along narrow country lanes.
description: 'along' is a preposition used to show movement of something in a line that follows the direction of something long.

proverb: They ran down the hill to the stream below.

proverb: Please take your papers off my desk. The wineglass fell off the table and shattered on the floor. He jumped off the platform.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition/adverb 'off' indicates movement away from the surface of (and often down) something

proverb: I've never been to the sea
description: We use the Present Perfect Tense to talk about experiences in our life. Here we are not talking about a particular sea, we are talking about sea in general. Similar examples: I've never been to the mountains, I've never been to the country (countryside)

proverb: They went up on to the stage. Move the kettle onto the counter. I slipped as I stepped onto the platform.

proverb: Take your hands out of your pockets and help me! He went out of the room to smoke a cigarette. Get out of the car!

proverb: We are flying over the mountains. The cat jumped over the wall.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'over' indicates movement above and across the top or top surface of something

proverb: A beautiful white bird flew over the lake. He threw the ball over the fence and it landed on the roof of a car.
description: These sentences demonstrate how to use prepositions of movement. The preposition 'over' indicates movement above and across the top or top surface of something

proverb: There's a gas station about a mile up the road.
description: 'Up' can be an adverb, a preposition or an adjective. We use 'up' as a preposition to talk about a higher position or movement to a higher position

proverb: Jack and Jill ran up the hill. The boat takes two hours going up the river and one hour coming down. We light the fire every night and that heats the room up.
description: 'Up' can be an adverb, a preposition or an adjective. We use 'up' as an adverb to talk about movement towards a higher position, value, number or level

proverb: The price of fuel is up again. It was cold yesterday but the temperature is up today.
description: 'Up' can be an adverb, a preposition or an adjective. We use 'up' as an adjective usually to talk about increases in prices, levels or amounts

proverb: The mouse ran under the chair. Submarines can travel under water.

proverb: We could see children in the playground as we drove past the school.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as an adverb and describes movement along something from one side to the other side of it

proverb: We gave the marathoners water as they ran past us.

proverb: The office is two blocks past the intersection.

proverb: Turn left just past the stairs.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as a preposition and indicates a location at the farther side of something, beyond a particular place

proverb: I'll meet you at half past five. It's exactly ten past three.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In these sentences 'past' is a preposition and is used for saying what time it is when it is not more than thirty minutes after one, two etc o'clock

proverb: Currently the leader of Germany is a woman. Past leaders have all been men.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this example 'past' acts as an adjective and basically means 'прошлый/прошлые'

proverb: It was past midnight by the time we arrived.
description: 'past' can be a noun, a preposition, an adverb or an adjective and has many uses. In this sentence 'past' acts as a preposition and means later than a particular time

proverb: I passed my test by studying past tests.
description: This sentence demonstrates the difference between two homonyms: 'passed' which is a verb (прошел, сдал), and 'past' which is an adjective in this case (прошлые). 'past' has many uses and it can act as a noun, an adjective, an adverb or a preposition

proverb: What would you have done?
description: This is an example of third conditonal sentence. We use third conditional to talk about hypothetical or unreal situations in the past, to imagine a different past.

proverb: I love chocolate. I hate spinach, but I like most other vegetables. I dislike paperwork. What do you want to eat? I want some chocolate.
description: love/hate/like/dislike/want are stative verbs. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Do you need some help? I need an umbrella. I need a ride.
description: 'need' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'Are you needing some help?', or 'I am needing something'

proverb: I prefer tea to coffee. I'd prefer not to work but I don't have much choice.
description: 'prefer' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am preferring ...'

proverb: She satisfies all the requirements for the job. His job satisfies him.
description: 'satisfy' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am satisfying ...'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective

proverb: I wish you were here.
description: 'wish' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am wishing ...'

proverb: I hope they get the punishment they deserve.

Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say '... they are deserving'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective - достойный, заслуживающий

proverb: You can do as you please. It pleases me to know that you liked the gift.
description: 'please' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'You can do as you are pleasing'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective

proverb: It doesn't surprise me that their parents don't want them to get married.
description: 'surprise' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'It is not surprising me'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective

proverb: This doesn't concern us at the moment.
description: 'concern' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'this is not concerning us ...'. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective or a preposition

proverb: We appreciate your invitation, and will attend the reception.
description: 'appreciate' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'we are appreciating ...'

proverb: I hear some music playing. Did you hear that?
description: 'hear' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am hearing music playing'. But we can say 'I am hearing voices', here hearing means imagining. 'hear' can also be used with 'ing' form as a gerund: hearing - слух, слушание, разбор

proverb: I see her now, she's just coming along the road. I've been seeing my boyfriend for three years.
description: Some verbs can be both stative and dynamic. 'see' as a stative verb means to see with your eyes / understand (first sentence). 'see' as an action verb means to meet / have a relationship with someone (second sentence)

proverb: I see what you mean. I'm seeing someone.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'see' as a stative verb means to see with your eyes / understand (first sentence). 'see' as an action verb means to meet / have a relationship with someone (second sentence)

proverb: I feel that this is not the best use of our time. I'm feeling sick.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'feel' as a stative verb is used when talking about someone's opinion (first sentence). 'feel' as an action verb is used when experiencing emotions or health issues, or touching something (second sentence)

proverb: I drink because it feels good. I've been feeling unusually tired lately. The doctor is feeling the pulse of a woman.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'feel' as a stative verb is used when talking about someone's opinion (first sentence). 'feel' as an action verb is used when experiencing emotions or health issues (second sentence), or touching something - щупать (third sentence)

proverb: I feel it still needs a lot of work. The vet was feeling the dog's leg to discover if it was broken.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'feel' as a stative verb is used when talking about someone's opinion (first sentence: I think it still needs ...). 'feel' as an action verb is used when experiencing emotions or health issues, or touching something - щупать (second sentence)

proverb: This cheese smells funky. He's smelling the cookies.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'smell' as a stative verb is used to describe the quality of smell possessed by something (пахнуть). 'smell' as an action verb is used when a person uses their nose to test something (нюхать)

proverb: The bar smells of smoke. She is smelling the flower.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'smell' as a stative verb is used to describe the quality of smell possessed by something (пахнуть). 'smell' as an action verb is used when a person uses their nose to test something (нюхать)

proverb: That doesn't sound right. You sound angry.
description: 'sound' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'that is not sounding right' or 'you are sounding angry'

proverb: This soup tastes great. The chef is tasting the soup.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'taste' as a stative verb is used to describe a flavor. 'taste' as a dynamic verb describes an action of tasting something (пробовать на вкус)

proverb: That cake looks delicious. He's looking at the computer screen.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'look' as a stative verb is used to describe appearance (выглядеть). 'look' as a dynamic verb describes an action of directing your eyes to something (смотреть). Also, as a dynamic verb 'look' forms a lot of phrasal verbs, such as 'look for - искать', 'look after - присматривать', etc

proverb: You look like shit. What are you looking at?
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'look' as a stative verb is used to describe appearance (выглядеть). 'look' as a dynamic verb describes an action of directing your eyes to something (смотреть). Also, as a dynamic verb 'look' forms a lot of phrasal verbs, such as 'look for - искать', 'look after - присматривать', etc

proverb: At what address does he live?
description: This sentence demonstrates how to use prepositions of place. We use the preposition 'at' with specific locations, addresses, public places, shops, hotels, homes etc

proverb: I did not object to the object
description: This sentence demonstrates how to pronounce 'object' as a noun and as a verb

proverb: Sorry, I don't remember your name. I remember my first day of school like it was yesterday. Do you remember when her birthday is?
description: 'remember' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am remembering my first day ...', or 'Are you remembering when ...?'

proverb: Do you know each other? I don't know the answer. I've known him for years.
description: 'know' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'Are you knowing each other?', or 'I have been knowing him for years'

proverb: He is funny. He is being funny. You are silly. You are being silly.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'be' is usually a stative verb and it is used to show a permanent quality or state of something/someone. But sometimes 'be' can be used as a dynamic verb to show a temporary quality or state, i.e. behaving or acting (only now, not usually). 'He is funny' (it's part of his personality) - он веселый (всегда), 'He is being funny'(he is temporarily behaving this way) - он шутит, он прикалывается (в данный момент), 'You are silly' (it's part of your personality) - ты глуп, 'You are being silly' (you are temporarily behaving this way) - Ты ведешь себя глупо (в данный момент)

proverb: I don't believe you. He believes in God.
description: 'believe' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am not believing you', or 'He is believing in God'

proverb: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
description: 'understand' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. We can't say 'I am not understanding ...'

proverb: I imagine they'll be here quite soon.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'imagine' is mostly used as a stative verb. We can substitute it with 'I think' or 'I am pretty sure'. But sometimes 'imagine' can be used as an action verb, when you are making something up in your head, for example: 'I am imagining things'

proverb: Things are seldom what they seem. It seems to be raining. It seems to me he isn't the right person for the job.
description: 'seem' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I doubt whether it'll work. No one doubts that the mission will be a success.
description: 'doubt' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: We agree with you. Frank and his wife disagree on this matter. Do you disagree with me?
description: 'agree' and 'disagree' are stative verbs. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Do you mind if I turn off the light? I don't mind if you don't mind.
description: 'mind' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: He finally realized the scope of the problem. I realize I was wrong. I realize I should have applied for the visa earlier.
description: 'realize' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: Do you realize the damage you've done?
description: 'realize' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I suppose you're right. I don't suppose you recognize me.
description: 'suppose' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. By the way, 'recognize' is also a state verb

proverb: I recognized her immediately. We didn't recognize you, without your beard.
description: 'recognize' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: She appears to be lost. There appears to be some mistake. Things aren't always what they appear to be.
description: The verb 'appear' has several meanings: to become noticeable/come into sight (появляться), to seem (казаться), to to perform publicly (исполнять), to arrive, and others. When it means 'to seem' it is a stative verb.

proverb: I didn't mean to hurt you. What do you mean by that? Material possessions mean nothing to me.
description: 'mean' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: I promise to be back soon. Those gray skies promise rain.
description: 'promise' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form. But it can be used with 'ing' form as an adjective.

proverb: I think you are right. I've been thinking about selling my house.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'think' as a stative verb means to believe, to have an opinion. 'think' as a dynamic verb means to reflect, to ponder - размышлять, раздумывать

proverb: I think that's a great idea. I'm thinking about my next holiday.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'think' as a stative verb means to believe, to have an opinion - считать, полагать. 'think' as a dynamic verb means to reflect, to ponder - размышлять, раздумывать

proverb: You are stupid. You are being stupid.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'be' is mostly used as a stative verb to show a permanent quality or state of something/someone. But sometimes 'be' can be used as a dynamic verb to show a temporary quality or state (only now, not usually). 'you are stupid' = you are always stupid, it's part of your personality, 'you are being stupid' = only now, not usually

proverb: It doesn't matter what you think. The only thing that really matters in life are your relationships to other people.
description: 'matter' is a stative verb. Stative verbs are verbs that express a state rather than an action. Action verbs can have both continuous and simple forms. Stative verbs are not normally used in the continuous form.

proverb: He denies breaking the window. I don't deny that I have made some mistakes. I'm denying myself desserts right now, while I'm on this diet.
description: The verb 'deny' is a stative verb when it means to say that something is not true - отрицать, or to refuse to give something to someone - отказывать (This government denies its citizens basic freedoms). But when it means to deprive oneself (of something) - лишать себя чего-то, it is a dynamic verb and can have both continuous and simple forms. It also demonstrates that if the verb 'deny' is followed by another verb (first sentence), this another verb must be a gerund

proverb: I have a car. I've had this car since 2006. I'm having problems with my car today.
description: Some verbs can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation. 'have' is mostly used as a stative verb and means to own, or to do regularly. We can't say: I've been having this car since 2006. But sometimes 'have' can be used as an action verb when taking or experiencing something: I'm having breakfast, I'm having fun, I'm having difficulty, etc

proverb: I have a headache. I am having a heart attack.
description: The verb 'have' can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation, and it is a little bit tricky with illnesses and conditions. If it is a long-term disease or illness that defines a person's long-term health or a single unchanging short-term condition, we usually say: I have a cold, I have cancer, I have a fever (think of it as a short-term illness). If it is a current health event that's in the process of changing significantly (heart attack, stroke, seizure, asthma attack) we say: I'm having a stroke, I'm having a seizure, etc

proverb: I have the flu. She is having a seizure.
description: The verb 'have' can be either stative or dynamic depending on the situation, and it is a little bit tricky with illnesses and conditions. If it is a long-term disease or illness that defines a person's long-term health or a single unchanging short-term condition, we usually say: I have a cold, I have cancer, I have a fever (think of it as a short-term illness). proverb: She is having a baby.

And also don't forget that certain verbs, such as 'keep', are always followed by a gerund. Most prepositions are also followed by a gerund: after, in, before, without, with, for, about, get used to, etc

proverb: Forgive me for being late. I can't forgive him for getting killed.
description: When one verb is followed by another verb, the second verb may be an infinitive (to go), bare infinitive (go) or gerund (going). The rule is to use a gerund after another verb when the second verb acts as the object of the first verb, 'being' and 'getting' are objects of 'forgive'. The verb 'forgive' is usually followed by an object + the gerund or 'for' + an object + the gerund. It can also be followed by a possessive adjective + the gerund: Forgive my being late. Forgive my saying so, but ... This rule also applies to 'excuse' and 'pardon'. Helps to remember: the preposition 'for' is always followed by a gerund

proverb: I go shopping every evening. I've gone camping five times this summer.

'go something' is often used to describe leisure activities that we do in our free time or do for fun: go running, go swimming, go hiking, go fishing, go kayaking, go berry picking, etc

proverb: It's hard for me to imagine having children. Imagine spending all that money on a coat!
